climbs.name: Yellow Jacket
climbs.fa: FA MA, KE 1971  FFA KR, DD 1978

content.description:
Climb an easy slab to the base of the vertical flake/crack. Climb the fantastic 5.10- crack to a stance below a roof. SQLIII shows turning the roof, however, I didn't see any pro up there so I took the obvious, and really fun sloper hand traverse left under the roof  into Squeeze Easy. From here another 100 feet of much easier climbing led to the top, but rope drag was hellacious. If I did the hand traverse option again I'd just belay on the ledge at the end of it and do another easier pitch to the top.  

  There didn't seem to be many other high quality routes in the area (The Sting looks high quality but neither of us wanted to tackle a Steve Grossman 11+). But this enjoyable crack route makes the short walk to the cliff worthwhile for the whimsical Mt. Lemmon crack enthusiast. I thought it was a strong two stars.
content.protection: All gear. Single set should be adequate for those "solid at the grade," but extras in 0.5 to 1 camalots were helpful. I placed a 4 in the obvious pod but it really isn't necessary.
content.location:
Yellow Jacket is on the right side of Lizard Rock's North Face, the middle of three parallel crack systems just before you reach the right end of the face. The leftmost crack is Squeeze Easy, 5.6, and the rightmost is The Sting, 5.11+. The route starts with an easy slab to reach the vertical crack. SQLIII shows turning a roof at the top of the crack, but it is also possible to hand traverse under the roof.  

  To descend, we walked to the top of Lizard Rock and found an anchor at the top of a bolted route to rappel from (belaying down to the anchor). This anchor was a bit old, and rappelling from a tree might be a better option--there are many in the vicinity. There also appears to be an easy 5th class downclimb, but it was wet. It would also be possible to walk off the northern end of the cliff, but this would be a long walk back to the base of the route.

content.description: A very mossy, lichen infested crack that might be worth a star if anyone ever spent an hour on it with a wire brush.  I only did it with a couple of falls on TR, so I'm guessing at the grade.  A lot of difficult stemming and some difficult hand jams in a flaring finger/hand crack. A bit of fun on TR.
content.protection: without a good cleaning this route would be scary on lead. setting a TR anchor is a headache.
content.location: the dihedral crack just to the left of the route 'Yikes' which has two bolts, the only bolts in the vicinity.

content.description: High Step from boulder onto slab across the sketchy left angling fall (need a spotter as you are immediately 7 ft up), and undercling the short wide crack.  Move up over crack through bulge of High Noon (5.9+X) [SQII].  Clip the bolt above the face, pull the bulge onto slab.  From third bolt continue on slab to top bulges instead of moving right to cracks.
content.protection: Three Bolts, then nuts and smaller cam sizes for runout and top bulge
content.location: End of wall (faces out toward Wind Point)

content.description: A very short route, maybe 4 or 5 moves.  Scramble halfway up the face to the actual climbing, put in a #2 and #3.  An awkward jam; pull onto a rounded, moss covered ledge; place another piece; 2 more jams, and  you're at the top.
content.location: near the middle of the N. side of Lizard Rock,  just 10 to 20 feet right of the route 'Yikes' which has 2 bolts (the only bolts you'll see in the area)

content.description:
Based off 'Squeezing the Lemmon III' (Go buy it!): Start on a low-angle ramp and climb the chimney to the left of Yellow Jacket. Work into a large, left-leaning flake.

 We did some fun chimney moves behind the left leaning flake. Make sure to manage rope drag well. A little run out in places unless you have big (>4 BD) gear but still fairly easy. Route has a decent amount of lichen.
content.location:
Walk all the way to the right side of the wall. There is a little rock tunnel we walked through before we got there but you could hike further away from the wall to skip this. To the left of Yellow Jacket.

 This wall is a lot longer then expected.

content.description: Starts on the triangular rock leaning against the face left of Tommyknockers.
content.location: Hike up to the N/W side, contour along the cliff, 3/4s of the way towards the S/W end.

content.description:
Climbs the southern arete on the west facing buttress. Farthest right of three semi-bolted lines here. 

  Seriously long run-out past first bolt through 15 ft of 5.11R slab climbing. There is serious deck potential on this slab.
content.protection: bolts, anchor to tree or boulder at top
content.location: right most of the three semi-bolted lines on the west facing buttress.

content.description:
This is the first route you will encounter on the trail. It follows a shallow water-groove up a near-vertical wall. Some people agree that this is a beautiful, pure line, others proclaim it silly. Go see it for yourself. It is an open project, not for lack a strong attempts, and is likely one of the hardest sport lines on the mountain. The name refers to the type of climbing you will encounter. Ninjas are awesome and they rule.  

  Note: a large tree has fallen against the base of this route and needs to be cleared but no bolts were damaged. It did clear a small pine that used to hug the wall to the right, where another seam exists. The section past that has been toproped to halfway and may hold more potential. Have at it.
content.protection: 5 bolts + chain anchors. You can rap in to the anchors from a tree at the top of the cliff.

content.description: Climb the ramp on thin slab to mint green stain on headwall. Follow the bolts from there to the chain anchors at the top.
content.protection:
bolts and chains  

  Loooong runout between first and second bolt, thus the R rating 

  Unless you are comfortable soloing 5.11, you'd be wise to top rope this one.
content.location: On the west buttress facing Windy Point. This is the middle line on this buttress between Twelve O'clock High (5.10 R) and Old Dude Attitude (5.12 R)

content.description: 20 feet of uninspiring climbing to a tree covered in ants.
content.location: rap down from and then climb back up to the second tree in from the end of the south side of the southwestern buttress

content.description: Start in the inside corner and work your way on to the right slab to the first bolt. Then climb the arÃªte.
content.location: Hike up to the N/W side, contouring along the cliff, 3/4s of the way towards the S/W end.

content.description: Upper-mountain grey stuff, Sport and trad, the best lines here are a couple cracks and a sick-hard slab, but other than that, not much else. Short hike but great camp spots nearby. Always in the shade. There is access to the top of the cliff.
